Die Bände unterscheiden sich in der Montage der Zeichnungen und Diagramme. 1628 wurde am Ende ein Anhang eingerichtet, der die Bilder enthält. 1633 wurden diese Blätter im Inhalt mit eingebunden.
Auf der Seite 160 wurde nur die Seitenzahl mit Bleistift korrigiert. Das mag der selbe Bibliothekar gewesen sein wie beim 1630er - Band ?!?? Ist schwer zu erkennen, da diese Stelle etwas überbelichtet ist.
Die Seite 215 ist ohne handschriftliche Anmerkung. Diese liegt nur der Paginierung folgend ordnungshalber dabei.
Zum Beispiel der Anhanggestaltung. Die Graphiken sind auf Photopapier erstellt. Stammen also sicherlich nicht aus 1628, oder was meinen Sie?

Der Band von 1633 enthält einige handschriftliche Zeilen auf dem fliegenden Vorsatzblatt - siehe Anhang. Die Seitenzahl 108 ist im Druck falsch gesetzt als 801. Dies wurde per Bleistift, vermutlich durch einen aufmerksamen Bibliothekar, verbessert.

analysis: Thank you for your enquiry about our copy of William Gilbert, De Magnete (London: Peter Short, 1600). I have looked at the volume, and there is only one page on which there are manuscript annotations. On page 206, there is a diagram entitled: “Diagramma notuum in orbibus magneticis”. Two straight lines have been added to the diagram in leadpoint. One is very thick, and actually comprises several lines that don’t entirely overlap each other, which bisect the circles, going through points E, G, [unnamed point], and L, and continuing in a straight line through the four additional unnamed points to the other side of the circles. The other line is singular, and is perpendicular to the first one, bisecting the circles through eight unnamed points. I include two photos.
provenance: It is likely that this book was owned by Seth Ward (1617-1689), who was the Savilian professor of astronomy at Oxford, and one of the founder member of the Royal Society, before becoming Bishop of Salisbury in 1667. Upon his death in 1689, he bequeathed half of his collection of printed books to Salisbury Cathedral. Unfortunately, the book was rebound in the nineteenth-century, and any provenance information (Ward had his own unique system of press-marks) has been lost.

provenance:
Unser Exmeplar 44 Phys. 2° findet sich auf Seite 1.000 im Bücherradkatalog und gehörte bereits im Oktober 1626 zur Büchersammlung von Herzog August (1579-1666). Dieser hat zwischen 1625 und 1627 seine bis dahin vorhandene Sammlung in einem Gesamtkatalog erfasst, der nach erster Beendigung 1627 als Zugangsbuch bis über Augusts Tod hinaus ergänzt und fortgeführt wurde. Ein genaueres Zugangsdatum ist nicht ermittelbar. Seit den 1640er Jahren befindet sich der Band vor Ort in Wolfenbüttel, nachdem Herzog August nach mehreren Jahren Wartezeit 1644 das Residenzschloss beziehen konnte.

In den ausgewerteten historischen Ausleihbüchern von 1664 bis 1806 konnte ich nur eine Entleihung des Bandes ermitteln.

Am 24. Februar 1676, also diese Woche Donnerstag vor genau 346 Jahren, wurde das Buch vom Küchenmeister und späteren Hochfürstlich Braunschweigisch-Lüneburgischen Haushofmeister Siegmund Georg Schöps (22.04.1632-17.04.1699) entliehen. Am gleichen Tag wurde ihm auch der folgende Band vorgelegt: https://opac.lbs-braunschweig.gbv.de/DB=2/XMLPRS=N/PPN?PPN=15103642X [Exemplar 8.2 Quod. (1)]

Es handelt sich um die ersten Entleihungen, die für Schöps belegbar sind. Bis 1696 hat er insgesamt zwölf Bände entliehen. Die Familie Schöps nutzte die herzogliche Bibliothek regelmäßig. Auch seine Ehefrau nimmt zwei Mal Einsicht in Handschriften ("gemalte Blumenbücher"). Der Sohn Rudolf Siegmund, Student in Helmstedt, entleiht innerhalb von zwei Jahren dreizehn Bände, das letzte nur wenige Wochen vor seinem Tod im Alter von 22 Jahren.

PHOTOS AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST.With woodcut caduceus device (McKerrow 119) on title page, large woodcut arms of the author on verso, 88 woodcut illustrations and diagrams in text (four full-page), large folding woodcut diagram (lightly browned) at page 200, fine decorative woodcut capitals, head- and tail-pieces. First edition of the first great work of experimental physics published in England; a scientific sturdy of electricity and magnetism. By his commitment to subjecting all theories to experiment, Gilbert became "among the first to initiate the experimental method of science" (Dibner). This work is one of the finest examples of inductive philosophy and even more remarkable for its publication two decades prior to Bacon's Novum Organum, where that method was actually explained for the first time. Throughout the De Magnete Gilbert discussed and usually dismissed previous theories concerning magnetic phenomena and offered observational data and experiments which would support his own theories. Most of the experiments are so well described that the reader can duplicate them if he wishes, and the examples of natural occurrences which support his theories are well identified. When new instruments are introduced (for example the versorium, to be used in identifying electrics), directions for their construction and use are included" (DSB).Gilbert's work is "the first major English scientific treatise based on experimental methods of research:" (PMM). Published only after eighteen years of personal study and experimentation, this book has Gilbert's new discoveries marked in the margins with large and small asterisks to denote whether they were significant or minor. Among the 21 major and the 178 minor discoveries is the conclusion that the earth is one large magnet (an assertion that led Galileo to study magnetism), as well as the invention of the versorium, his electroscope or electrometer, the first instrument devised to measure electrical phenomena. His magnetic theory enabled him to explain the behavior of the compass-needle, the dip-needle, the magnetic condition of vertical masses of iron, and the magnetic properties of heated iron bars when allowed to cool while lying in the magnetic meridian. In Book 2, which was intended as a digression into the importance of amber ("electrum") to magnetic studies, Gilbert coined the terms "electricity", "electric force" and "electric attraction" - clearly establishing his reputation as the founder of electrical science.Gilbert also claimed another, less coveted kind of scientific repute by coming to see magnetism as the explanation for almost all phenomena. This led Francis Bacon to attack him in his Sylva Sylvarum (1626) as being "one of those people so taken up with their pet subject of research that they could only see the whole universe transposed into the terms of it" (Butterfield, p. 56). This singular, scientific phenomena persists into our own days with numerous scientists currently describing major elements of the universe as working "exactly like the computer". All known copies have numerous ink emendations (not noted in the errata) which some have suggested shows that Gilbert saw the edition through the press personally. The present copy has manuscript corrections on pp. 11, 14, 22 and 47 - but not on p. 63 as seen in some copies. Contemporary limp vellum with overlapping edges. Spine lettered manuscript but faded. Foot of spine expertly repaired. Newer endleaves. Title lightly browned with a few tiny repairs, final few leaves evenly browned with lower margins repaired, some spotting. Cloth folding case. Overall, a lovely copy. PHOTOS AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST. Bestandsnummer des Verkäufers 229
